awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Rapid Blood Typing with a Portable Medical Device
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is the creation of a faster, more portable, affordable and reliable blood typing and red blood cell concentration test. This is important because trauma centers and hospitals rely extensively on blood donations provided by blood banks across the U.S. to save lives. There are currently 84 million blood typings per year in the U.S., with approximately 16 million donations annually. Processing costs approach $200 per pint of blood, so the ability to pre-screen donors by blood type and selectively direct the donation process (i.e. plasma, red cells) would result in significant savings and bolster our declining blood supply. This portable technology could also be translated to remote geographical locations for disaster relief applications. This blood analysis microdevice will enhance scientific and technological understanding by exploring the use of electric fields to identify cell differences. In addition, the potential initial economic impact is expected to be up to $12 million per year, which will contribute to the U.S. competitiveness in healthcare including trauma, blood therapies, and surgeries. 


The proposed project will play a key role in miniaturizing the bulky supporting power supply infrastructure currently surrounding microfluidic device operations. The proposed project will translate optical analysis of cell responses into a pattern algorithm that outputs the result via a user-friendly interface. Lastly, this project will combine two separate microfluidic devices into a single prototype interfacing with the portable power supply and algorithm to simultaneously discern blood type and hematocrit. This work advances scientific knowledge and will be published after securing proper IP. It is also a powerful alternative to expensive antigen/antibody molecular recognition reactions for medical diagnosis for future point of care diagnostic applications.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the development of a handheld device for blood typing and hematocrit testing. Development and third party review of a full design model and wire diagram for the device were completed. Two generations of hardware prototypes were designed, built, and tested. The associated software developed underwent three revisions to address errors and reliability issues that arose during testing. Two enclosures were designed and machined, and the entire device was used to test blood samples under laboratory conditions. The device has proven reliable and robust, completing over 100 tests to date. Concurrent work on another related project also enabled us to concurrently match video microscopy recordings (optical) with capacitive sensing measurements (electrical), increasing accuracy and testability of our device.

 

This project also allowed the development of cheap, disposable testing strips to be used with the device. During this project, our team iterated and tested 3 generations of designs for the disposable strips. We tested a new microfabrication approach that allowed us to make planar specialized electrodes to easily test hematocrit. This project also allowed us to refine the strip and device configuration, with the end result being the development of two distinct disposable strips, one that tests hematocrit alone, and one that tests both hematocrit and blood type. This allows a lower cost hematocrit strip to displace the more expensive options currently in use by our potential customers, as well as a hybrid strip that allows our customers to expand their capabilities to screen and guide donors to specialized donations in response to real time demand. Additionally, all stages of the microfabrication were meticulously characterized with calibration curves and characterizations to facilitate smooth transition to larger scale microfabrication facilities.

 

This project supported the development of image analysis algorithms to quickly determine unique blood type “profiles”, which we have made available to our lab technicians through a user-friendly web interface. The web interface enabled technicians to upload a microscopy video from the experiment, define experimental parameters, and quickly see the results of a given experiment. This enabled additional algorithm optimizations such that the resulting profile is a highly accurate quantification of the recorded video cell responses. Further, the database resulting from this work allows for easy comparison between blood types and experiments to ascertain reproducibility which was used to conduct statistical analysis.

 

Finally, this project supported the growth and expansion of several individuals. The PI developed skills for developing versatile and process-efficient image analysis such that video analysis can be conducted for an 8 minute experiment in roughly 30 seconds. The postdoctoral scholar supported on this project has been trained in microfabrication, had tangential training in electronics design and testing, and expanded his skill set in device design simulations and electrokinetic microfluidics.  He has gained experience in small business processes. Additionally, the microfabrication effort developed the skills of three additional students whose time was split between this project and a related project. For the electronics design and build, the skills of one technical engineer were enhanced; he oversaw the development and training of one very talented undergraduate student who completed the wiring diagrams, PCB design, and learned the mechanical build of the devices. The knowledge and experiences of the PI on the subcontract were greatly enhanced by learning skills outside of her immediate discipline including the PCB designs and microfabrication tools.
